title: 110_hr3253
content: The Act is titled the "Measuring and Evaluating Trends for Reliability, Integrity, and Continued Success Act." It amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 by adding a section on data systems and requirements. The "Measuring and Evaluating Trends for Reliability, Integrity, and Continued Success Act" requires states receiving funds to develop a longitudinal data system for public charter schools within 4 years. States must form an advisory committee with members experienced in data system development within 6 months of enactment. The "Measuring and Evaluating Trends for Reliability, Integrity, and Continued Success Act" mandates states to establish a committee with diverse backgrounds for developing a longitudinal data system for public charter schools. The data system must include a unique statewide student identifier and student-level enrollment information. The "Measuring and Evaluating Trends for Reliability, Integrity, and Continued Success Act" requires states to create a longitudinal data system for public charter schools. This system includes student-level enrollment, demographic, program participation information, academic assessment score matching, reasons for non-participation, and data on student entrance and exit from the education system. The "Measuring and Evaluating Trends for Reliability, Integrity, and Continued Success Act" mandates a statewide audit system for data quality, a unique teacher identifier, student transcript details, and the ability to link education data from preschool to higher education and workforce systems. The data system required by the "Measuring and Evaluating Trends for Reliability, Integrity, and Continued Success Act" may include student-level data on participation and performance in college admissions and placement assessments. It must ensure privacy of student records, effective data architecture and storage, and the ability to link student records over time and databases for standardized or customized reports. The data system required by the Act must be based on informational needs at various levels, include all required data elements, allow for longitudinal analysis, support program evaluations, ensure interoperability among software interfaces, with other state and local systems, and with migratory systems. The Act requires interoperability with migratory student records system, electronic data portability, professional development, researcher access to data, and protection of employee rights. States with preexisting data systems can use them for this purpose. The Act requires states to certify their data systems meet requirements before implementation. $150,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2008 and subsequent years. States will receive an allocation of funds, with 50% distributed equally. The Act requires states to certify their data systems before implementation. States will receive funds based on enrollment, with 50% distributed equally. The Secretary will allot funds after the state submits an application. Penalties may apply if substantial progress is not made within three years. Funds can be used for allowable purposes after certification. The funds received can be used to maintain, operate, and upgrade data systems, provide data integrity training, offer professional development on data collection and usage, and develop processes to enhance teaching and learning through data analysis. The Secretary reserves funds for a State education data center grant, with a maximum of $2,000,000, to support data system operations and improvements. Nonprofit entities can apply for the grant by submitting an application. Entities applying for the State education data center grant must submit an application to the Secretary with required information. The grant will be awarded through a competitive process, and applicants must assure seeking private funds, provide a plan for financial support, and demonstrate experience in education data system development. The State education data center grant recipients must use funds for technical assistance, best practices dissemination, and data repository functions. Data must be made publicly available in compliance with privacy laws.
